articles.author: Ryan Trimble
articles.description:
I know, I know: there are a ton of content management system options available, and while I've tested several, none have really been the one, y'know? Weird pricing models, difficult customization, some even end up becoming a whole 'nother thing to manage.
Using Pages CMS for Static Site Content Management originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Using Pages CMS for Static Site Content Management

articles.description:
What does it look like to refactor your own code? John Rhea picks apart an old CSS animation he wrote and walks through the thought process of optimizing it.

articles.title: Orbital Mechanics (or How I Optimized a CSS Keyframes Animation)

articles.description:

articles.description:

articles.description:
The CSS shape() function recently gained support in both Chromium and WebKit browsers. It's a way of drawing complex shapes when clipping elements with the clip-path property.

articles.description:

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine ‚Äî For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Rebecca Hemstad & Mark Malek)
articles.description: Learn how two designers tackled the challenges of building a localization-ready design system for a global audience. This case study dives into how Rebecca and Mark combined Figma Variables and design tokens to address multilingual design issues, such as text overflow, RTL layouts, and font inconsistencies.
articles.title: Integrating Localization Into Design Systems

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Miko≈Çaj Dobrucki)
articles.description: The Penpot team is not slowing down on its mission to build a free design tool that not only offers powerful design features but is also well-integrated with code and modern development practices. In its latest release, Penpot, as the first design tool ever, introduces support for native design tokens. Let‚Äôs take a closer look at this concept and how you can employ it in your process.
articles.title: Integrating Design And Code With Native Design Tokens In Penpot

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Clarke)
articles.description: Have you ever thought about how the limitations of early cartoon animations might relate to web design today? From looping backgrounds to minimal frame changes, these retro animation techniques have surprising parallels to modern CSS. In this article, pioneering author and web designer [Andy Clarke](https://stuffandnonsense.co.uk) shows how he applied these principles to Emmy-winning composer Mike Worth‚Äôs new website, using CSS to craft engaging and fun animations that bring his world to life.
articles.title: Smashing Animations Part 1: How Classic Cartoons Inspire Modern CSS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Gabriel Shoyombo)
articles.description: There were duelling proposals floating around for adding support for masonry-style layouts in CSS. In one corner is a proposal that extends the existing CSS Grid specification. In the other corner is a second proposal that sets up masonry as a standalone module. Well, not until recently. Now, there are three proposals with Apple WebKit‚Äôs ‚ÄúItem Flow‚Äù as the third option. The first two sides make strong points, and the third one merges them into one, all of which you will learn about in this article.
articles.title: Masonry¬†In CSS: Should Grid Evolve Or Stand Aside¬†For¬†A¬†New Module?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: When was the last time your project wrapped up smoothly ‚Äî no delays, no surprises, no last-minute compromises? In reality, most UX projects drift as timelines slip, budgets stretch, and features morph. How do we get better at navigating the chaos? An upcoming part of How To Measure UX and Design Impact by yours truly.
articles.title: How To Launch Big Complex Projects

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Mikhail Prosmitskiy)
articles.description: WCAG is evolving. Since 1999, the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines have defined accessibility in binary terms: either a success criterion is met or not. But real user experience is rarely that simple. WCAG 3.0 rethinks the model ‚Äî prioritizing usability over compliance and shifting the focus toward the quality of access rather than the mere presence of features. Could this be the start of a new era in accessibility?
articles.title: WCAG 3.0‚Äôs Proposed Scoring Model: A Shift In Accessibility Evaluation

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: The new month is just around the corner, and that means: It‚Äôs time for some new desktop wallpapers! All of them are designed with love by the community for the community and can be downloaded for free. Enjoy!
articles.title: Make Every Day Count (May 2025 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Anima Team)
articles.description: As designers, it‚Äôs important to be able to transform visual ideas into concepts within minutes and into fully functional products within hours. Well, today we‚Äôre bringing you closer to AnimaApp, an app designed to make your life easier ‚Äî whether you‚Äôre a designer, developer, product team member or entrepreneur.
articles.title: How To Turn Your Figma Designs Into Live Apps With Anima Playground

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Lost in a sea of UX files, docs, PDFs, and scattered decisions across Slack, Dropbox, Notion, and Figma? We talk a lot about organizing Figma, but what about a sensible folder structure for all UX assets? Let‚Äôs fix that. Kindly powered by [Smart Interface Design Patterns](https://smart-interface-design-patterns.com).
articles.title: UX And Design Files Organization Template

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Talke Hoppmann-Walton)
articles.description: It starts with good intentions ‚Äî a quick fix here, a shiny feature there ‚Äî and suddenly, your product portfolio‚Äôs bursting at the seams. In this guide, Talke Hoppmann-Walton walks you through a ‚ÄúProduct Kondo‚Äù exercise to declutter, realign, and spark some serious product joy for both your business and your customers.
articles.title: ‚ÄúProduct Kondo‚Äù: A Guide To Evaluating Your Organizational Product Portfolio

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Marina Chernyshova)
articles.description: While it is clear that creativity is driven by both the left and right hemispheres, an important question remains: how can we boost creativity while keeping the process enjoyable? It may not be obvious, but non-design-related activities can, in fact, be an opportunity to enhance creativity.
articles.title: Boosting Up Your Creativity Without Endless Reference Scrolling

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Amejimaobari Ollornwi)
articles.description: Poor internet connectivity doesn‚Äôt have to mean poor UX. articles.title: What Does It Really Mean For A Site To Be Keyboard Navigable
